label: Undated Letter 3 from Gertrude Sanford Legendre
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, lecturing him on how he needs to take better care of himself, relaying information about how their children are doing, and discussing a scheme she thinks will allow her to join him in Hawaii. Gertrude continues in her letter to describe her job and daily routine.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
April 12th
This morning as I had hoped the postman brought me three envelopes from
you and Oh I was thrilled. First darling you do look thin in your 
picture.As beautiful and hansome as ever but you have really lost weight.
I do wish you would not work on Sunday. It is too much, and you will get
sick and than lose alot of time in the end. Take care of yourself
please darling. Getting overtired, nervousand exhausted never pays.
In the end you will get sick and working at all will be agony. Stop be
fore it is too late, before you have a nervous bre[a]kdown. Remember
one's health comes first, There is nothing on earth more important than
keeping well. Try and stop that Sunday work of yours. Mrs Bott would c
certainly agree with me. Even tho' there is a war and you have to do the 
limit of all you can on your job never the less- it will break you
down so you and by being useless. The old constitution can only take
so much and no more.
Your long letter of April 3rd was wonderful. How I enjoyed
every part of it. By now you have received so[m]e of mine telling you 
how having to join the WAACS has prevented me from going over seas. 
Children stand in my way and I am here no doubt till the war is over,
and you return to me which will be such heaven. 
I agree with most everything you say about tho Planation. 
We will enjoy it for three months perhaps but not all the time. We will 
run it with w[a]ter and Rosa in a simple kind of way and live somewhere
in the sunshine to-gether with a house with big windows and lots of 
light and air. Doodles, and maybe one servant to wash the dishes.
I agree about letting Melle. go but it is so very hard to make the 
break as Landlne told me a week agao how she adored Melle and that never 
never must I let her go. It will upset her so terribly I hate to do
it and funnily enough Landine does not like Miss Evans, she said so. 
She said she is scared of Miss Evans. Rose tells me Miss Evans is not
crazy abo[u]t Landine,so I guess they each know tho other does n't care
much for each other- with makes matters awfully difficult. Ofcourse
soon Landine will be older- and it will be much easier. I wish it was
boarding school time right now. I talked this all over with Miss,Charlotte
and she advised me to leave this a s they are for the time if,I could
and if financially I could still swing it,as she thought it was not the
moment for the wrench. I feel she knows children so much better than I do
that I am tempted to be guided in a way by her. What do you think?
Now that you tell me your Captain wrote a swell letter
recommending you two- I can now see where that Commander the other night
got the dope that you two were such stars. It has evidently traveled.
around the Navy Department in short order. I am so glad. I know you two
are too good for the Job. You two can do anything. Absolutely anything,  
and I believe before the war is over you will have a much more important
post. I am sure of it. I certainly hope so.
Darling I did not say five hundred cables a day. I get 
in 100-a day but put five hundred cover sheets on them. Because there 
are five copies of every cable that I have to rout to different
[End Page 1]
2
desk heads. It is a busy days work and there is little time to breathe.
Remember I told you I had an assistant, a secretary and two stenographer
s plus a messenger boy- all under me at My Cable Desk. It keeps us 
all six busy for nine hours or ten every day. The volume mounts all the
time and soon I shall have to take on an other worker to handle the
growing business. Its far and away the most fun of any part of the offi
as you g[e]t all the red hot news, all the dope, and it takes speed and a
action which suits me down to the ground. So far I am the only girl
on this floor that has not had a day off because ef sickness. I 
get tired- sure but I seem to sleep ten hours every now and again and 
come back fresh as a daisy. Its a pity with my health and endurance wh
[which I can see is far greater than most gals] that I have not got
something to do like driving an ambulance at the front. I would be g
good at that am sure, and wish it was what I was doing right now.
You would really feel you were helping those poor guys in a big way
and really doing something. This work is all remote control.
Please Darling when and if your plans change let me know. I
shall be right here I am sure an 1528 31st Street waiting for your
letters.
I am so sorry you are getting so tired and overworked-Please
try and take care of yourself and get a rest and change on Sunday
-It really does n't pay to over do it. You know it too.
Did you ever get my flowers to cheer your apartment. Yours ar
arrive regularly and are so lovely and gay and its such a thrill
to open them and know they are from you sweet ears. Its heaven. 
I love you and miss you and long to hold you and kiss you.
So long darling. I must stop as I have so much work to do.
Gertie -
P.S. Believe me there would be little chance of Rose going to London
with me at any time. Its an believably difficult thing to get
to London or anywhere and unless you have specific job it cant be done.
Rationiing in England is severe and no extra mouths are wanted to feed.
Of course I would want her with the children any way -
She is so marvelous - I dont know how
the house would ever run with out her -
She cooks, orders, washes, cleans [and] takes care of
everything [and] keeps things looking so nice
[and] neat - I wish you were in my
little house - you would love it so -
It is cozy [and] gay [and] clean, [and] the garden
run is cunning with the daffodils
blooming -
[End Page 2]
